main event: Unidentified radar sightings were reported in Greenland from 27 March 1953 to 26 February 1953, and the observations were ultimately attributed to weather phenomena.
interesting points: The radar sightings were attributed to meteorological conditions or weather effects on the scope, indicating no known identifiable targets.
The report mentions the existence of a temperature inversion at an altitude of 3300 feet and possibly at the 4600 feet level, along with the corresponding upper air temperatures.

An unidentified aircraft was observed climbing and accelerating rapidly to approximately 50,000 feet, traveling at an estimated speed of approximately 1,300 knots, and fading from the scope after being tracked for a distance of three miles.
The report states that the data obtained was not sufficient to explain the unidentified sightings or provide any conclusive evidence as to their identity.
The sightings were considered as phenomena type and were ultimately attributed to a reflection or a meteor-like phenomenon.
